question.title: Truncate an array without copying it?

node.contents: In Java, is there a way to truncate an array without having to make a copy of it? The common idiom is Arrays.copyOf(foo, n) (where the new array is n elements long). I don't think there is an alternative, but I'm curious as to whether there is a better approach.

astNode.text: In Java, is there a way to truncate an array without having to make a copy of it? The common idiom is Arrays.copyOf(foo, n) (where the new array is n elements long). I don't think there is an alternative, but I'm curious as to whether there is a better approach.

node.contents: +1, Arraylists are very nice if you're trying to manipulate the size of things or remove elements efficiently.

astNode.text: +1, Arraylists are very nice if you're trying to manipulate the size of things or remove elements efficiently.

node.contents: An array's length in Java cannot be altered after initialization, so you're forced to make a copy with the new size. Actually, the length parameter of a Java array is declared as final, so it cannot be changed once it's set.

astNode.text: An array's length in Java cannot be altered after initialization, so you're forced to make a copy with the new size. Actually, the length parameter of a Java array is declared as final, so it cannot be changed once it's set.

node.contents: If you need to change an array's size, I'd use an ArrayList.

astNode.text: If you need to change an array's size, I'd use an ArrayList.

node.contents: No way. You could story somewhere the truncated lenth but it would not be the value returned by array.length.

astNode.text: No way. You could story somewhere the truncated lenth but it would not be the value returned by array.length.

node.contents: I was thinking about it some more... and just for kicks, how about something like the below.

astNode.text: I was thinking about it some more... and just for kicks, how about something like the below.

node.contents: Note: This is just a "can it be done?" intellectual exercise in Java hacking. Anybody who attempts to actually use this idea in production code will deserve all the pain that will undoubtedly follow.

astNode.text: Note: This is just a "can it be done?" intellectual exercise in Java hacking. Anybody who attempts to actually use this idea in production code will deserve all the pain that will undoubtedly follow.

elements.contents: public class Foo { private static byte[] array = new byte[10]; public static void main(String[] arg) throws Exception { Field field = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); field.setAccessible(true); Unsafe unsafe = (Unsafe) field.get(null); Field arrayField = Foo.class.getDeclaredField("array"); long ptr = unsafe.staticFieldOffset(arrayField); // doesn't work... there's gotta be a way though! unsafe.reallocateMemory(ptr, 5); System.out.println("New array size is: " + array.length); } }

comments.text: // doesn't work... there's gotta be a way though! unsafe.reallocateMemory(ptr, 5); System.out.println("New array size is: " + array.length); } }

node.contents: Succinctly: No, There isn't, as far as I know. A Java array is a fixed-size data-structure. The only way to "logically" resize it is create a new array and copy the wanted elements into the new array.

astNode.text: Succinctly: No, There isn't, as far as I know. A Java array is a fixed-size data-structure. The only way to "logically" resize it is create a new array and copy the wanted elements into the new array.

node.contents: Instead: You could (possibly) implement a class which wraps an array into a collection and uses a "size" variable to logically reduce the length of the array without actually copying the values. This an approach has limited utility... The only case I can imagine where it's practical is when you're dealing with a huge array, which just can't be copied because of memory limitations.

astNode.text: Instead: You could (possibly) implement a class which wraps an array into a collection and uses a "size" variable to logically reduce the length of the array without actually copying the values. This an approach has limited utility... The only case I can imagine where it's practical is when you're dealing with a huge array, which just can't be copied because of memory limitations.

node.contents: Copying an array is relatively inexpensive time-wise... unless you're doing it millions of times, in which case you probably need to think up an algorithm to avoid this, and not waste your time mucking around with a "variable length array".

astNode.text: Copying an array is relatively inexpensive time-wise... unless you're doing it millions of times, in which case you probably need to think up an algorithm to avoid this, and not waste your time mucking around with a "variable length array".

node.contents: And of course... you could just use an ArrayList instead. Yes?

astNode.text: And of course... you could just use an ArrayList instead. Yes?

node.contents: I don't believe so. An array is allocated as a contiguous block of memory, and I can't imagine that there is any way of releasing a part of that block.

astNode.text: I don't believe so. An array is allocated as a contiguous block of memory, and I can't imagine that there is any way of releasing a part of that block.
